name: Words by Decade 1921-1930 Quiz | Words by Decade | 10 Questions

questions.text: Which of the following is the true definition of "bingle"?
options: a type of jazz music popular in the 1920s
a person who runs a beauty salon
a type of necklace studded with diamonds
questions.explanation:
a short hairstyle for women.

	The word "bingle" is an interesting blend of "bob" and "shingle". Its use was recorded in "Punch" magazine in 1925 in the sentence about a lady complaining to her hairdresser that her "bingle" had been bungled.

questions.text: Which of the following is a 1920s word for a chorus girl?
options: chorette
chorice
chorelle
questions.explanation:
chorine.

	John Ayto in his book "20th Century Words" records its first use in 1922. It was originally used in the U.S.A. and lasted for all of the period up to the Second World War after which its popularity declined.

questions.text: What were the ingredients of "Eskimo pie" first recorded in the vocabulary of the U.S.A. in 1928?
options: elk meat coated in flour
bear meat wrapped in pastry
ice cream coated with meringue
questions.explanation:
ice-cream coated with chocolate.

	This was originally a brand or proprietary name first recorded as just "Eskimo" in 1922. In Britain its equivalent was the "choc-ice" but the first record of that word is in 1951.

questions.text: A mainly British expression which originated in the 1920s was a "blue-eyed boy". What does it mean?
questions.correct: someone who benefits from preferential treatment
options: someone who has never grown up emotionally
someone who is extremely handsome
someone with very young features
questions.explanation:
someone who benefits from preferential treatment.

	The expression describes someone who is always the favourite (U.S.A. spelling "favorite"). They have probably been spoiled as a child and have got used to things always going their way.

questions.correct: a musical instrument similar to a saxophone
options: an athlete
a type of glue or adhesive used for sticking posters or bills
a man who gets all the dirty jobs
questions.explanation:
a musical instrument similar to a saxophone.

	This word is first recorded in 1928. The goofus had 25 finger-holes, each with its own reed, and therefore was capable of producing chords. Its failure to stay the distance as a popular musical instrument is probably due to its silly name.  The word is often used now to refer to a foolish person.

questions.correct: a slang name for a car
options: a slang name for a microphone
a slang name for the radio
a slang name for the talking picture cinema
questions.explanation:
a slang name for a car.

	This word did not survive the 1920s. A variant on "buzz-box" was "buzz-wagon". It possibly derives from moving from place to place in your car like a bee moving between flowers.

questions.text: What other meaning did the word "radish" gain in the U.S.A. during the 1920s?
questions.correct: someone who pretended to be a communist but wasn't
options: someone who pretended to be an Italian but wasn't
someone who pretended to be a fascist but wasn't
someone who pretended to be of Irish origin but wasn't
questions.explanation:
someone who pretended to be a communist but wasn't.

	The idea was first put forward by Trotsky. The radish was chosen because it is red on the outside but white on the inside.

questions.text: What is the meaning of the word "treen" which first entered common usage in Britain in 1927?
options: extremely handsome and attractive
an abbreviation of the number thirteen
having a very rough and rugged surface
questions.explanation:
wooden dishes and utensils.

	This word was a legacy of the Arts and Crafts movement. However, "treen" as an adjective meaning "wooden" dates back to the Old English period. As a noun it is now most likely to be heard when people are discussing antiques.

questions.correct: a bird that is the offspring of a swan and a goose
options: a man whose job was to tighten bolts on steel erection sites
a person who is likely to faint at any time
a looping  manoeuvre in stunt flying
questions.explanation:
a bird that is the offspring of a swan and a goose.

	Genetic manipulation has thrown up other hybrids such as "tigon" (1927), "liger" (1938) and "geep" (1971).

questions.text: The personality test known as the "Rorschach test" was first employed in the 1920s. What was the nationality of the man who devised this ink-blot clue to character?
options: German
American
Danish
questions.explanation:
Swiss.

	Hermann Rorschach (1885-1922) first came up with this idea by which a standard set of ink blots of different shapes and colours is presented one at a time to a subject with the request that he or she should describe what they suggest or resemble.
